citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection there was Medetomidine Hydrochloride (20 mg/ml injection, Lot No.: 222-06144820) solution, a
sedative drug which expired on January 29, 2025, located in the locked cabinet in Back of House Tigers which could have
been used on said animals. This was confirmed with the facility representative that was present. Usage of expired drugs
can cause injury and/or suffering to the animals and can be ineffective for their intended use.
When reviewing preventative care records for the older female African serval, it was revealed that facility personnel
improperly administered multiple doses of Bravecto – a topical flea and tick preventative. The required frequency of
administration is once every 2-3 months, as confirmed with the facility representative and veterinarian. The serval
received dosages monthly on the following dates: 7/22/2024, 8/22/2024, 9/23/2024, and 10/22/2024. In addition, when
reviewing medical records for the African Crested Porcupine, it was discovered that on January 24, 2025, facility
personnel administered injectable Ivermectin. The medication should not have been administered to this animal, as
confirmed by the facility representative and the veterinarian. Failure of personnel to properly administer medications to the
animals can negatively affect their health and well-being.
Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
Correct by: As of the date of this inspection on June 30, 2025, and going forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of inspection there was Medetomidine Hydrochloride (20 mg/ml injection, Lot No.: 222-06144820) solution, a 
sedative drug which expired on January 29, 2025, located in the locked cabinet in Back of House Tigers which could have 
been used on said animals. This was confirmed with the facility representative that was present. Usage of expired drugs 
can cause injury and/or suffering to the animals and can be ineffective for their intended use. 
 
When reviewing preventative care records for the older female African serval, it was revealed that facility personnel 
improperly administered multiple doses of Bravecto – a topical flea and tick preventative. The required frequency of 
administration is once every 2-3 months, as confirmed with the facility representative and veterinarian. The serval 
received dosages monthly on the following dates: 7/22/2024, 8/22/2024, 9/23/2024, and 10/22/2024. In addition, when 
reviewing medical records for the African Crested Porcupine, it was discovered that on January 24, 2025, facility 
personnel administered injectable Ivermectin. The medication should not have been administered to this animal, as 
confirmed by the facility representative and the veterinarian. Failure of personnel to properly administer medications to the 
animals can negatively affect their health and well-being.  
 
Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate 
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.  
 
Correct by: As of the date of this inspection on June 30, 2025, and going forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
